entry.title: Combined summary - Auto-generated miner backbone
entry.summary: The email conversation between Michael Gronager, Mike Hearn, and Peter Todd discusses potential changes to the Bitcoin protocol to address a vulnerability in the mining process. Todd suggests adding two rules to relay all blocks that meet the PoW target and relay block headers that nearly meet the PoW target. The goal is for miners to always mine to extend the block that the majority of hashing power is trying to extend. However, Hearn and Gronager propose alternative solutions that may be less complex and have fewer implications. One suggestion involves building a miner backbone by embedding IP addresses of nodes into coinbases, while the other involves eliminating the first seen rule. Additionally, there is concern about the potential for biasing peers into preferring to mine on blocks with near-PoW headers by selectively blocking them. Overall, the discussion centers around improving the security of the Bitcoin network by making it more difficult to partition the majority hashrate.
